Dear Sir,

I am very sorry for any inconvenience I may have caused you.

My memory is failing me, but I remember that my parents told me I was the first white baby in the locality and my mother was 20 years old when I was born.

The Indians that came to the house and stole our food. They were very kind and did not harm us.

The school was a small wooden building, hunching around the wall, no chairs but the mud at the teacher's desk. We used slates to write on. I was only four and our first teacher just taught him Scottish rhyming.
I am writing to express my deep concern regarding the recent developments in our community. The situation has become increasingly tense, and I believe it is crucial that we come together to address these issues.

Firstly, I would like to acknowledge the efforts made by the local authorities to maintain order. However, I have noticed an uptick in incidents that seem to be escalating the tension further. It is essential that we find a way to resolve these conflicts peacefully.

Secondly, I urge everyone to remain calm and composed. Let us focus on finding constructive solutions rather than allowing emotions to run wild. We must work towards a future where everyone feels safe and respected.

In conclusion, I urge all members of our community to come together and find common ground. Together, we can overcome any challenge.

Sincerely,

A word of explanation to the person answering the questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use every sheet of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or personal examples, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answering anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

APRIL 11, 1955
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to you, while others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if necessary as not sufficient space to answer the questions.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Ontario before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

23. In there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

We saw the first train that came into Saskatchewan. We all went to town for the day travelling by oxen. Remember the committee in charge cooking potatoes in large cauldron and the large crowd eating meals.
